channel.title: Data Is Plural
channel.description: A weekly newsletter of useful/curious datasets.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.03.08 edition
item.description: Government contracting data, debt-to-income ratios, changes of address, decades of UK prices, and shows cut short.
item.content:encoded:
Government contracting data, debt-to-income ratios, changes of address, decades of UK prices, and shows cut short.

Â 

Government contracting data, cataloged. The nonprofit Open Contracting Partnership has launched a registry of government procurement datasets that use its Open Contracting Data Standard (featured in DIP 2020.02.26). The registry contains 100+ entries so far, across 50+ countries â€” from Argentinaâ€™s national roads authority and the city of Buenos Aires to Zambiaâ€™s Public Procurement Authority. You can filter the listings by dataset recency, update frequency, and the data types included (parties, awards, documents, amendments, et cetera). [h/t Georg Neumann]

Â 

Debt-to-income ratios. The US Federal Reserve generates quarterly statistics estimating the median ratio of household debt to income in each state, county, and metro area. The published maps and datasets, which go back to 1999, donâ€™t include precise figures, but rather place each geographic unit into one of ten ranges. The income calculations come from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, while the debt estimates (which do not include student loans) come from the New York Fed Consumer Credit Panel, â€œan anonymized 5 percent random sample of Americans with credit files at the credit reporting bureau Equifax.â€ As seen in: â€œDebt and Inequalityâ€ (American Inequality).

Â 

Â 

Changes of address. In the â€œFrequently Requested Recordsâ€ section of its online FOIA library, the US Postal Service provides datasets counting how many individuals, families, and businesses have registered for the agencyâ€™s change-of-address service, by month and ZIP code. The datasets tally the moves originating from a given ZIP code separately from those destined for it, although moves within the same ZIP code are counted on both sides of the ledger. Related: The companies to which USPS sells mover-level data. [h/t Tim Henderson]

Â 

Decades of UK prices. In January 2023, the UKâ€™s Office for National Statistics collected 139,000+ price quotes from thousands of stores and across hundreds of products, from â€œA4 PRINTER PAPER (500 REAM)â€ to â€œYORKSHIRE PUDDING FROZENâ€. The agency has collected this kind of price-quote data for decades, using it to calculate inflation and price indices. Economist Richard Davies has aggregated the data going back to 1988 and standardized it, correcting misrecorded prices, offsetting measurement changes, among other efforts described in a 2021 working paper.

Â 

Shows cut short. IsItCutShort.com provides a searchable list of television shows that were canceled (e.g., Knight Rider), ended on a cliffhanger (The Sopranos), or both (Rubicon). The database provides each seriesâ€™s title, cliffhanger and cancellation status, IMDB identifier, and occasional extra notes. A handful of the 130+ entries fit another category: shows that â€œended without a cliffhanger, but more show content exists outside the show itself.â€ [h/t Dan Brady]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send unrenewed feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Place an ad in Data Is Plural.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.03.01 edition
item.description: Congressional votes and ideology, EPA-regulated facilities, programming languages, 20th-century occupations, and coconut thumps.
item.content:encoded:
Congressional votes and ideology, EPA-regulated facilities, programming languages, 20th-century occupations, and coconut thumps.

Â 

Congressional votes and ideology. The Voteview project â€œallows users to view every congressional roll call vote in American history,â€ and places those votes in the context of ideology estimates along a liberal-to-conservative spectrum. The core estimates come from DW-NOMINATE, a method developed by the projectâ€™s directors emeritus, Keith T. Poole and Howard Rosenthal. Voteviewâ€™s bulk data includes ideology estimates for every member of the House and Senate since 1789, every vote taken in either chamber, and every memberâ€™s position on those votes. [h/t Philip Bump]

Â 

EPA-regulated facilities. The US Environmental Protection Agencyâ€™s Facility Registry System â€œprovides Internet access to a single source of comprehensive information about facilities, sites or places subject to environmental regulations or of environmental interest.â€ It includes each entityâ€™s name, type, location, industry, regulatory programs, and more. That information, which spans millions of facilities, is â€œsubjected to rigorous verification and data management quality assurance procedures.â€ The records also provide facilitiesâ€™ ID numbers from other EPA systems, such as the agencyâ€™s Risk Management Program database featured in last weekâ€™s edition. [h/t Michael Allen]

Â 

Programming languages. PLDB is a database that describes several thousand programming languages, file formats, communications protocols, and other related concepts. Its downloads, available in several formats, provide information on the languagesâ€™ years announced, technical features, creators, countries and communities of origin, relevant books and URLs, popularity metrics, and more. [h/t Derek M. Jones]

Â 

20th-century occupations. Between 1939 and 1991, the US government published several iterations of the now-discontinued Dictionary of Occupational Titles, a precursor to the O*NET database (DIP 2017.09.27). The dictionaries included job descriptions, classification codes, and cross-references, but are mostly available only as scans. So Shahad Althobaiti et al. organized the manual transcription of five major editions into structured text files. A random sample of 1939â€™s titles: punch-press operator, seam dampener, base brander, box pleater, and necktie finisher.

Â 

Thump, thump, coconut. â€œTraditionally,â€ in the Philippines, â€œcoconuts are classified into their maturity levels manually,â€ June Anne Caladcad and Eduardo Piedad Jr. write. â€œTraders often use their fingernails, knuckles, or the blunt end of the knife to tap the coconuts before assessing the sounds produced.â€ The authors and their colleagues have developed hardware and software to emulate that process, and used it to collect acoustic signal data from 129 premature, mature, and overmature coconuts, each mechanically knocked on each of its three ridges.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send overmature feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Learn how to place an ad in Data Is Plural.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.02.22 edition
item.description: Facilities handling hazardous chemicals, Animal Welfare Act inspections, daily European gas imports, unclaimed estates, and data journalists.
item.content:encoded:
Facilities handling hazardous chemicals, Animal Welfare Act inspections, daily European gas imports, unclaimed estates, and data journalists.

Â 

Facilities handling hazardous chemicals. The US Environmental Protection Agencyâ€™s Risk Management Program rule requires facilities that handle â€œextremely hazardous substancesâ€ to tell the government, at least every five years, about those substances, their safety plans, their recent accident history, and more. Through a FOIA request to the EPA, the Data Liberation Project (which, disclosure, I run) obtained a copy of the agencyâ€™s database of these filings (minus some parts the government deems non-disclosable), containing submissions by 21,000+ facilities from early 1999 to February 2022. You can now access that data, in various formats, along with documentation guiding you through it.

Â 

Animal Welfare Act inspections. The USDAâ€™s Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service checks whether animal dealers, exhibitors, research facilities, and transporters are complying with the care standards set by the Animal Welfare Act. The agency provides public access to the inspection reports but no bulk data on them. So, in a collaboration between Big Local News and the Data Liberation Project (same disclosure as above), Ben Welsh and I wrote code to fetch the 80,000+ (and counting) inspections going back to 2014, parse their PDFs, and make the data more accessible. The information includes each inspectionâ€™s date, type, licensee, violation counts, species inspected, and more.

Â 

Daily European gas imports. Researchers at Bruegel are tracking daily and weekly natural gas imports to Europe, using data from the European Network of Transmission System Operators for Gasâ€™s transparency portal. Alongside the imports, which theyâ€™re aggregating by source (e.g., Russia, Norway, Algeria) and by route (e.g., Nord Stream, TurkStream), the researchers are also tracking gas storage levels, using data from Gas Infrastructure Europe (DIP 2022.01.26). Previously: Eurostatâ€™s data on annual European energy imports and exports (DIP 2022.03.16).

Â 

Unclaimed estates. The UK governmentâ€™s Bona Vacantia division publishes a dataset of unclaimed estates â€”Â inheritances that nobody has claimed yet to inherit. The entries indicate the deceased personâ€™s name, aliases, date/place of birth and death, marital status, and more. Related: California provides a dataset of unclaimed property, such as â€œlost or forgottenâ€ bank accounts, insurance benefits, and stock holdings.

Â 

Data journalists, surveyed. The European Journalism Centerâ€™s DataJournalism.com has published a dataset of 1,800+ anonymized responses to its second annual State of Data Journalism Survey, including 50+ entries each from the US, UK, Italy, Germany, Spain, India, and Nigeria, plus double-digit counts from dozens of other countries. The questions touch on demographics, employment, training, skills, the COVID-19 pandemic, and more. [h/t Simona Bisiani]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send data-reported feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Learn how to place an ad in Data Is Plural.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.02.15 edition
item.description: Fair market rents, humanitarian groups, diplomatic visits, bog bodies, and Open Data Day events.
item.content:encoded:
Fair market rents, humanitarian groups, diplomatic visits, bog bodies, and Open Data Day events.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Free workshop! Iâ€™m teaching a PDF-parsing class at NICAR 2023 in a couple of weeks. Iâ€™d like to test out the material by teaching it online first. If youâ€™re interested (and have some experience with Python), click here.

Â 

Fair market rents. Every year, the Department of Housing and Urban Development recalculates what it calls â€œfair market rentsâ€ for every county in the US and for individual ZIP codes in metropolitan counties. The results, which factor into various housing subsidy programs, represent the 40th percentile cost of monthly rent and (basic) utilities for â€œrecent moversâ€ in â€œstandard qualityâ€ units, adjusted for the number of bedrooms. HUDâ€™s annual spreadsheets go back to the early 2000s; you can also browse the estimates online and query them via an API. As seen in: â€œWhere are rents rising post COVID-19?â€ (USAFacts).

Â 

Humanitarian groups. â€œBased on clear and reproducible criteria,â€ Clara Egger and Doris Schopper have compiled the Humanitarian Organizations Dataset, which describes 2,500+ groups active in the sector. It includes the organizationsâ€™ founding years, structures, countries headquartered, regional scopes, types of activities, targets for assistance, and more. You can also explore a version of the dataset online. Related: The Global Database of Humanitarian Organisations, from Humanitarian Outcomes, â€œa team of specialist consultants providing research and policy advice for humanitarian aid agencies and donor governments.â€

Â 

Diplomatic visits. The US Department of Stateâ€™s Office of the Historian maintains a dataset and online directory of every visit by a foreign leader from 1874 to 2020. The details include each visitâ€™s starting and ending date, the visitorâ€™s name, their country, and a brief description. The office publishes similar data on the travels of US presidents and secretaries of state. Related: Matt Malis and Alastair Smith have expanded the data for 1946â€“2019, adding fields that indicate the type of visit, whether it involved a presidential meeting, the names of agreements signed, and more. Previously: Diplomatic gifts (DIP 2022.08.03).

Â 

Bog bodies. Roy van Beek et al. â€œpresent the first large-scale overview of well-dated human remains from northern European mires, based on a database of 266 sites and more than 1000 bog mummies, bog skeletons and disarticulated/partial skeletal remains.â€ The database, which can be found in the studyâ€™s supplementary materials tab, indicates the bog bodiesâ€™ location, year found, preservation level, sex, estimated age, assumed cause of death, and much more. [h/t Miriam Posner + Robin Sloan]

Â 

Open Data Day events. Open Data Day(s), scheduled for March 4â€“10 this year, â€œis an annual celebration of open data all over the world.â€ The Open Knowledge Foundation, which helps to coordinate the locally-organized gatherings, hosts a searchable list of registered events, plus datasets of each yearâ€™s events since 2014.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send open feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. // Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. // Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. // Learn how to place an ad in Data Is Plural.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.02.08 edition
item.description: African American biographies (1508â€“1865), foreign direct investment, Indiaâ€™s high-court judges, US aquifers, and prognosticating groundhogs.
item.content:encoded:
African American biographies (1508â€“1865), foreign direct investment, Indiaâ€™s high-court judges, US aquifers, and prognosticating groundhogs.

Â 

African American biographies, 1508â€“1865. The African American National Biography, first printed in 2008 and expanded to a twelve-volume second edition in 2013, is â€œthe most extensive African American biographical encyclopedia ever compiled, including the widest range of historically significant black individuals possible.â€ Edited by Henry Louis Gates, Jr. and Evelyn Brooks Higginbotham, the print volumes feature nearly 5,000 entries, with additional biographies published in an online collection (subscription required). Executive editor Steven J. Niven has created a dataset describing the 1,300+ people in the encyclopedia born before the US abolition of slavery. It includes their names, dates and places of birth, occupations, whether they were ever enslaved and/or freed before abolition, how they obtained freedom, and much more.

Â 

Foreign direct investment. Among its many activities, the Bureau of Economic Analysis collects data on US-owned businessesâ€™ direct investments abroad and those by foreign-owned businesses in the US. The agency provides statistics based on that data, aggregated by industry and country. The metrics, available as spreadsheets and interactive tables, include cumulative investments, overall transaction flows, foreign affiliatesâ€™ employee counts, and more. As seen in: â€œWhy are US companies investing more abroad?â€ (USAFacts).

Â 

Indiaâ€™s high-court judges. Know Your High Court Judges, a multi-institution collaboration, has compiled biographical and professional data on all 1,700+ judges appointed to Indiaâ€™s high courts (each state and union territoryâ€™s top appellate court) between late 1993 and mid-2021. The details, based on a range of official sources, include each judgeâ€™s name, gender, date and place of birth, dates of appointment and retirement, courts served, prior experience, and more. [h/t Apoorv Anand via csv,conf,v7]

Â 

US aquifers. Merhawi GebreEgziabher et al., seeing several shortcomings of the US Geological Surveyâ€™s aquifer location data for â€œlocally relevantâ€ research, decided to build the United States Aquifer Database. It delineates the boundaries, constructed â€œafter reviewing hundreds of primary literature sources,â€ of 440 aquifer systems in the contiguous US â€” from the Abbotsford-Sumas Aquifer straddling the Washington-Canada border to the Biscayne Aquifer in southern Florida. Read more: A visual tour of twelve aquifers.

Â 

Prognosticating groundhogs. Paul Craigâ€™s Groundhog-Day.com calls itself â€œthe leading data source for North Americaâ€™s prognosticating groundhogs and their yearly predictions.â€ Its structured data lists the names, descriptions, locations, and prediction histories for 74 real and â€œalternativeâ€ groundhogs, the latter of which include Lucy the Lobster and Dover Doug, a human in a groundhog suit.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send six more weeks of feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. â€¢ Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. â€¢ Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. â€¢ Learn how to place an ad in Data Is Plural.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.02.01 edition
item.description: Womenâ€™s well-being, radiation-contaminated waste, novel dialogue, browser capabilities, and more English football.
item.content:encoded:
Womenâ€™s well-being, radiation-contaminated waste, novel dialogue, browser capabilities, and more English football.

Â 

ğŸ“£ Ad: Access all the data your business needs, with Bright Data; from complete structured datasets to developing web scrapers fast and on a mass scale. Take control of your data strategy with our all-in-one solution. Get a dataset sample today!

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ In last weekâ€™s newsletter, I noted that the Coast Guardâ€™s list of boat recalls â€œseems possible to scrape.â€ Reader Michael Nolan took up the challenge; hereâ€™s the dataset he extracted. Thanks, Michael!

Â 

Womenâ€™s well-being. Camille Belmin et al.â€™s LivWell dataset presents â€œa set of key indicators on womenâ€™s socio-economic status, health and well-being, access to basic services and demographic outcomesâ€ in 447 regions of 52 countries from 1990 to 2019. The indicators include, for example, rates of home ownership, educational attainment, and domestic violence; theyâ€™re based primarily on data from the Demographic and Health Surveys Program, a USAID-funded initiative that, since 1984, â€œhas provided technical assistance to more than 400 surveys in over 90 countries, advancing global understanding of health and population trends in developing countries.â€ Read more: An introductory Twitter thread from Belmin.

Â 

Radiation-contaminated waste. The US Nuclear Regulatory Commission regulates the disposal of â€œlow-levelâ€ radioactive waste â€” â€œitems that have become contaminated with radioactive material or have become radioactive through exposure to neutron radiation,â€ such as protective equipment and cleaning supplies. The NRC provides annual statistics (facility, volume, and total curies) for the countryâ€™s four active disposal sites. The Department of Energyâ€™s Manifest Information Management System provides more detailed figures, with breakdowns by month, state of origin, waste classification, isotope, and more. Previously: Data from the Nuclear Fuel Data Survey (DIP 2022.11.23).

Â 

Novel dialogue. Krishnapriya Vishnubhotla et al.â€™s Project Dialogism Novel Corpus contains every quotation from 22 novels, plus who speaks each line, who theyâ€™re addressing, the characters they mention, and more. With 35,000+ quotations, the corpus â€œis by an order of magnitude the largest dataset of annotated quotations for literary texts in English.â€ Jane Austen is the most-represented author (five novels), followed by E.M. Forster (two). The researchers have also published a document that they â€œhope will help standardize future annotation work in this domain.â€

Â 

Browser capabilities. Alexis Deveriaâ€™s caniuse.com indicates which versions of which web browsers support various web technologies, such as CSSâ€™s grid layout, the WebP image format, and the Image Capture API. The projectâ€™s dataset covers 530+ technologies and 19 browsers (6 desktop, 13 mobile). It also provides estimates of the percentage of all users whose browsers support a given technology. [h/t Simon Willison]

Â 

More English football. Josh Fjelstulâ€™s English Football Database â€œis a comprehensive database of football matches played in the Premier League and the English Football League from the inaugural season of the Football League (1888-89) through the most recent season (2021-22).â€ It records each season, team, match, and the standings table at the end of each season. Previously: James P. Curleyâ€™s English soccer dataset (DIP 2016.05.04), since expanded to leagues in a dozen more countries. [h/t Derek M. Jones]

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send premier feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. â€¢ Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. â€¢ Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. â€¢ Learn how to place an ad in Data Is Plural.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.01.25 edition
item.description: More recalls, jazz solos, overdose-related â€œGood Samaritanâ€ laws, upcoming weather, and cats on the move.
item.content:encoded:
More recalls, jazz solos, overdose-related â€œGood Samaritanâ€ laws, upcoming weather, and cats on the move.

Â 

More recalls. DIP 2023.01.11 featured vehicle recall data from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Other US federal agencies publishing recall data include the Food and Drug Administration, whose dataset contains 81,000+ entries related to food, drugs, medical devices, and related products going back to 2012; the Consumer Product Safety Commission, whose database spans 8,500+ recalls since 1973; and the Coast Guard, whose listing of 1,600+ boat recalls is not downloadable but seems possible to scrape. [Update, 2023-02-01: Reader Michael Nolan took up the boat-recall challenge; hereâ€™s the dataset he extracted.] Also: Vehicle recall data from Canadian and UK regulators. Previously: International medical device recalls from ICIJâ€™s Implant Files (DIP 2019.04.17).

Â 

Jazz solos. The Jazzomat Research Project, hosted at the University of Music Franz Liszt Weimar, aims â€œto investigate the creative processes underlying jazz solo improvisations with the help of statistical and computational methods.â€ The projectâ€™s main database contains transcriptions and analyses of 450+ solos by John Coltrane, Charlie Parker, and dozens of other artists. The downloadable version includes each â€œeventâ€ in each solo: its pitch, loudness, time of onset, duration, and more. As seen in: â€œWhat makes that song swing? At last, physicists unravel a jazz mysteryâ€ (NPR). [h/t Juan Pablo MarÃ­n DÃ­az]

Â 

Overdose-related â€œGood Samaritanâ€ laws. Shane W. Reader et al. have compiled data on US state laws that â€œprevent or mitigate criminal consequences for activities pertaining to controlled substances for persons who call 911 to report a drug overdose.â€ Their dataset spans April 2007 to June 2022 and covers all 50 states, plus DC. The details include the types of people protected (e.g., the person overdosing, the caller, self-reporters), the kinds of protection conferred (e.g., with regard to arrests, charges, sentencing), the types of violations protected, and more.

Â 

Upcoming weather. Alexander Reyâ€™s Pirate Weather aims to be a â€œdrop in replacementâ€ for DarkSkyâ€™s weather forecast API, which is shutting down. It pulls data from several NOAA forecast models in order to provide minute-level, hourly, and daily predictions of temperature, precipitation, cloud cover, and more. Note: The API is free to use but is limited to 20,000 calls per month. Related: Pirate Weather powers Merry Sky, a website built by Guillaume Carbonneau. [h/t Giuseppe Sollazzo]

Â 

Cats on the move. Between 2013 and 2017, Roland Kays et al. convinced hundreds of volunteers in the US, UK, Australia, and New Zealand to strap GPS sensors on their pet cats. The aforelinked datasets include each catâ€™s characteristics (such as age, sex, neuter status, hunting habits) and timestamped GPS pings. Related: CatTracker.org, the homepage for the US branch of the project, features a cat-track browser. Previously: Cat meows (DIP 2021.06.30). [h/t Rika Fujiwara + Soph Warnes]

Â 

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send feline feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. â€¢ Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. â€¢ Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. â€¢ Learn how to place an ad in Data Is Plural.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.01.18 edition
item.description: Unreturned remains, money in UK politics, Brazilian biodiversity, government open-source policies, and food coloring.
item.content:encoded:
Unreturned remains, money in UK politics, Brazilian biodiversity, government open-source policies, and food coloring.

Â 

ğŸ‘‹ Will you be attending NICAR 2023? If so, click here to propose a â€œData Blitzâ€ presentation; Iâ€™ll be moderating the event.

Â 

Unreturned remains. â€œThe remains of more than 110,000 Native American, Native Hawaiian and Alaska Nativesâ€™ ancestors are still held by museums, universities and federal agencies,â€ according to The Repatriation Project, a ProPublica investigative series launched last week. The projectâ€™s interactive database provides more detailed figures â€” such as counts by institution, tribe, and geography. It builds upon National Park Service databases that track institutional compliance with the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act, including each institutionâ€™s self-reported counts of human remains and funerary objects not yet made available for return and compliance updates published in the Federal Register. Event: ProPublica is hosting a webinar at 4pm US Eastern today.

Â 

Money in UK politics. The Westminster Accounts, a recent collaboration between Sky News and Tortoise Media, examines the flow of money through UK politics. It does so by combining data from three key sources: the Register of Membersâ€™ Financial Interests, Electoral Commission records of donations to parties, and the Register of All-Party Parliamentary Groups. You can search and explore the results through the collaborationâ€™s interactive database. They havenâ€™t published a downloadable version yet, but Simon Willison has extracted one. Read more: The projectâ€™s methodology.

Â 

Brazilian biodiversity. Flora e Funga do Brasil, a project led by the Rio de Janeiro Botanical Garden Research Institute, aims to collect â€œmorphological descriptions, identification keys and illustrations for all species of plants, algae and fungi known to the country.â€ With the help of hundreds of scientists, the project currently covers 50,000+ species. A downloadable dataset links each speciesâ€™ various names and synonyms, geographic distribution, reference citations, and more. [h/t Grist Labs]

Â 

Government open-source policies. Researchers at the Center for Strategic and International Studies have compiled a dataset of 660+ government policies regarding open-source software proposed at the national level since 1999. The dataset indicates each proposed policyâ€™s country, year, title, issuing authority, stated objective, status, and more. The countries with the largest number of entries: Argentina, the US, and South Korea. [h/t Kevin Xu]

Â 

Food coloring. Arlie L. Lehmkuhler et al. have used high-performance liquid chromatography to assemble a dataset measuring the levels of â€œFD&Câ€ color additives (e.g., Yellow 5 and Red 40) in foods and drinks popular with children, such as breakfast cereals and fruit-flavored soft drinks. The results, organized by product category, include product- and dye-specific measurements, but do not name the particular products or brands.

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send artificial feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. â€¢ Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. â€¢ Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. â€¢ Learn how to place an ad in Data Is Plural.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.01.11 edition
item.description: Automobile recalls, small-business loans, European Parliamentarians, variable stars, and NYC pizza slices.
item.content:encoded:
Automobile recalls, small-business loans, European Parliamentarians, variable stars, and NYC pizza slices.

Â 

ğŸ“£ Ad: Will your 2023 include a project that needs geocoding? Check out OpenCageâ€™s geocoding buyerâ€™s guide to learn all the factors to consider when deciding on which geocoding service to use, and thus avoid â€œI wish I had known that before we started.â€

Â 

Automobile recalls. In the US, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration oversees all recalls of vehicles, tires, child safety seats, and other auto equipment. Through the agencyâ€™s recall portal, you can search by vehicle identification number, make, model, and year; for other types of recalls, you can search by brand and model. The agency also provides a dataset of all 26,000+ recalls since 1966. It lists the recall type, manufacturerâ€™s name, component, number of units potentially affected, and date the manufacturer notified NHTSA, plus descriptions of the problem, recall action, and remedy. [h/t Chartr]

Â 

Small-business loans. The US Small Business Administration publishes loan-level data from two of its major lending programs, known as 7(a) and 504, going back to the early 1990s. The records, updated quarterly, indicate each loanâ€™s amount, term, interest rate, approval date, and current status; borrower type, name, and location; bank name and location; and more. As seen in: The Black Wealth Data Centerâ€™s business ownership indicators. Previously: SBA data on loans provided through the pandemic-instigated Paycheck Protection Program (DIP 2020.07.08).

Â 

European Parliamentarians. Political scientist Eugenio Salvati has created a dataset of all European Parliament members whoâ€™ve held office for at least one month since 1979, the EU legislative bodyâ€™s first year of direct elections. For each five-year cycle, Salvatiâ€™s spreadsheets list each memberâ€™s name, country, gender, parliament role, EP political group, local political party, previous political experience, and more. Entries for the 2019â€“2024 cohort also indicate committee membership. Previously: LobbyFacts.eu (DIP 2017.08.02).

Â 

Star light, star bright. A variable star is one whose brightness appears (from Earth) to vary over time. The American Association of Variable Star Observers, founded in 1911, maintains a database of â€œtens of millions variable star observations going back over one hundred years,â€ making it â€œthe largest and most comprehensive digital variable star database of its kind in the world.â€ You can download star details from the associationâ€™s star index, and also download any given starâ€™s set of observations. [h/t Peter Corless]

Â 

NYC pizza slices. â€œStarting in 2014, I logged every slice of pizza I ate in New York City on the Instagram account NYC Slice,â€ writes reporter Liam Quigley, who has published a map, price chart, searchable table, and spreadsheet of the first 464 slices. The data include each sliceâ€™s date, location, style, and price. â€œI did not rate the slices to avoid controversy and bribes. The biggest thing I have noticed is the decline in the amount of sauce put on slices.â€

Â 

Dataset suggestions? Criticism? Praise? Send saucy feedback to jsvine@gmail.com, or just reply to this email. â€¢ Looking for past datasets? This spreadsheet contains them all. â€¢ Visit data-is-plural.com to subscribe and to browse past editions. â€¢ Learn how to place an ad in Data Is Plural.

item.title: Data Is Plural â€” 2023.01.04 edition
item.description: Prison-banned books, severe weather warnings, congregations and adherents, UAE art establishments, and one billionaireâ€™s donations.
item.content:encoded:
Prison-banned books, severe weather warnings, congregations and adherents, UAE art establishments, and one billionaireâ€™s donations.

Â 

Prison-banned books. The Marshall Project is building a database of books banned from state prisons, based on official lists that reporters requested from each stateâ€™s correctional agency. The browsable and downloadable database includes roughly 50,000 entries from 18 states so far, with plans for expansion. The fields include the bookâ€™s title, author, date banned, and reason for banning, although availability varies by state. (Disclosure: I did some contract work for this project, extracting data from PDFs.) Read more: â€œWhy Would Prisons Ban My Book? Severe weather warnings. Among its many services, the Iowa Environmental Mesonet provides a range of National Weather Service data interfaces and downloads, including current and historical severe weather warnings, watches, and advisories. Coverage for tornado, severe thunderstorm, flash flood, and marine warnings goes back to 1986; in more recent decades, the data include dozens of additional phenomena, such as freezing fog, high surf, dense smoke, and excessive heat. The records indicate each alertâ€™s geospatial boundaries, time of issuance and expiration, forecast office, status, and more.

Results for the 2021 study, available as spreadsheets and maps, include responses from 370+ faith groups. Previously: The National Congregations Study (DIP 2021.12.29). [h/t Adam Porter]
